reviewText: I'll make this short and sweet.\n\nSimply put, this is just another lazy cashgrab in a long line of lazy cashgrabs by this developer. The Lost Souls is a sequel" to White Mirror - except it's practically the same game with a different color palette. Same setting
votesTotal: assuming it doesn't crash. (It's worth noting
votesFunny: the game didn't crash for me like it apparently did for others) The "puzzles" are literally just typing words backwards in order to open locked doors. Unfulfilling
column16: senseless tripe. I'm sure the same will be said about the next game this developer uploads about 3 months from now

reviewText:
about 20 minutes of playtime and about 20 crashes...nuff said

its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you enter a new zone

its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you try to save game because you are afraid to that the game will crash and you will be in the previous zone

its a 50/50 chance it will crash when you try to load game, because you have crashed already but managed to save your game

10/10 would crash again

reviewText:
I don't know where this bloody influx of FPS Creator titles has come from and, frankly, it doesn't matter so long as we can assemble a team to burn it to the ground but, in the meantime, I sure hope you like your stages like an eight year old girl likes her bowling lanes: separated by GIANT CRASH BARRIERS.

Without fail, every area transition (of which there are only a merciful four) sent me hurtling back to the desktop with the gratingly familiar FPSC has stopped working" taunt that is becoming far more familiar in my gaming pursuits than is acceptable. Occasionally you get a "root system error" when you try to save as well which I guess is the closest thing this abomination is going to get to variety.

The Lost Souls is atrociously written
date:
horrendously translated and is honestly about throwing seven switches over fifteen minutes. Never buy it. Never play it. This would be considered an abuse of human rights by the government in a George Orwell novel.

Sheer garbage awaits your eyes below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=obRqRrv6y9U"

reviewText:
The game crashes a LOT. The graphics, except for the water, are sub-par and the story negates any fear of dying as you are already dead. That said it's slightly better than most low budget horrors that stumble onto steam, but this is not hard to achieve. The puzzles are hilariously simple and the game has NO options menu whatsoever. The occasional environment can look okay, but the textures elsewhere bring the game down.

Would only recommend if you're already dead IRL and need a reason to be glad about it.

For my full review with screenshots:
https://koolthingsforkoolkids.wordpress.com/2016/04/11/why-did-i-play-the-lost-souls/

reviewText:
This game kinda felt like a recycled White Mirror, which is another game this developer made. I'm very easily scared, but this game really didn't do it for me. I only played it for about 15 minutes so far, but its very remeniscent of the first game the developer made, which I thought was very dull. Still, its a VAST improvement over that game. I didn't experience any crashing, as other reviews point out, so I guess that's a plus. I wouldn't recommend this game, as it just lacks excitement for me.

Here is a few minutes of gameplay if you want to check it out:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cRqGsq_DyfI

reviewText: I was intrigued by the theme of this game and knew it had a significant number of bad reviews. I went ahead and got it anyway assuming other players were exaggerating. I found out that they were not exaggerating. It is a very short game which is generally empty in spite of the screenshots. The few monsters this game has are programmed in a way that they do not react to you, but merely follow a predefined path. The English is extremely bad and I would have expected the developer to let this game be reviewed by someone else more proficient in it. The story is only half a story. The puzzles are too trivial to even be in the game. You have to keep using the SHIFT button to move a little bit faster as without it, you would be bypassed by snails if they were in the game. The game has a replay value of 0. You can probably finish it in 20 - 50 minutes and will then never 'play' it again. As far as I am concerned most demos are more polished than this game. It really could have become something with a LOT of effort, but the developer apparently did not feel the need to do so and apparently chooses to keep selling empty games like this one in different formats. Unfortunate. The game does have a clever marketing strategy to draw players in, but that is all it has. In all fairness the game does have scary moments and they are not badly done, but they are very scarce and at some point you just know the full extent of what the game does and does not do and the surprises then end there. I just expected a lot more and a lot better.\n\nIn this case it was not a case of whether the game was good enough to play. No, it was a matter of whether the game was good enough to be in my library. I did not consider this game worthy to remain in my library and thus permanently removed it from my library.
